reviewText: First of all, it's a Rankin/Bass animagic special, so I think I could just stop there, because that says it all!This is a great Easter movie, with Peter Cottontail learning about responsibility in order to be the head bunny.  The Characters are wonderful as usual, An evil bunny, french caterpillar, and a talking Easter bonnet joining Peter in his journey back in time.  It is Set in the beautiful April Valley and narrated by Sassafras(Danny Kaye), with, as always, great songs. My faves being "Here Comes Peter Cottontail" and "If I could Only Get Back to Yesterday".Also, as extra value for money, you get one of R/Bs cartoon features, "Puss In Boots".  I don't know how many of you would remember these cartoons, but the introductions starts with a book spiralling into the centre of the screen.  It then opens up and says Rankin Bass presents.......whatever cartoon it is, then all the different characters walk over a rainbow.  When I started watching it, all these memories started flooding back to me from when I was little, it was such good fun to watch.  Definitely worth having.I am in my twenties and still enjoy watching R/B productions, true, that is because I grew up with them, but anybody who hasn't tried some Rankin/Bass, please do, you will be pleasantly suprised!
summary: Join Peter on his bunny trail

reviewText: Although "Amimagic" studios Rank & Bass produced over a dozen Christmas specials, they only made one Easter show and this is it!  Charming re-imagining of the Peter Cottontail fable, with a year's worth of kid appeal.  We follow Peter, who overslept and missed his attempt to become Official Easter Bunny, as he travels through one-year's time and almost every major holiday on the calendar.  Think "Santa Claus Is Coming To Town" meets "Holiday Inn." I only wish the cute music packed an Irving Berlin punch.
summary: Only Rank & Bass Easter Classic charms

reviewText: This is an excellent stop-motion TV special that originally aired during the early 70's. It features the voices of Danny Kaye, Vincent Price and Casey Kasem and is the first and easily the best of three Easter specials from Rankin/Bass, who also graced our television sets with holiday traditions such as "Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer", "Santa Claus is Coming To Town", "Frosty the Snowman", and the popular cult classic "Mad Monster Party".This fanciful, pastel-colored Easter special is based on a book titled "The Easter Bunny Who Overslept". Peter Cottontail agrees to a contest against Evil Irontail to see who can deliver the most Easter eggs. But, when Peter oversleeps, leaving Evil Irontail to rule April Valley (the land of Easter bunnies), he must travel back through time making unplanned stops at all the other holidays on his way back to Easter.This show really has a warm, Easter/Spring feeling, wonderful songs and a chance to catch a glimpse of all the holidays through the enchanted puppet-animated world of Animagic! Once again, Rankin/Bass have taken that fuzzy holiday warmth and turned it into a colorful, fun special.**This newest release from 2010 features a beautifully restored print that is ears and tails above all the others. Remastered in high definition, the colors pop and things that were blurry in the background in previous releases are now crystal clear. It is not completely without a few specks and scratches here and there, but do you really want to watch these old specials without a few of those? Definitely worth the double-dip if you are a fan!
summary: Rankin/Bass' Easter Masterpiece in a Sparkly New Edition!

reviewText: In the Easter bunnies' special land called April Valley, a decision is being made of who will be the new Chief Easter Bunny, and Peter Cottontail seems to be the most likely candidate. However, wicked Irontail has his sights set on the job too, and a contest ensues for the coveted role. Unfortunately, thanks to one of Irontail's evil tricks, Peter oversleeps and fails at the task of handing out more eggs than his competitor. So, the job goes to the dastardly Irontail, who wishes to change things completely, including painting Easter eggs mud brown and concrete gray and commissioning chocolate tarantula and octopus sculptures instead of the usual chocolate bunnies and eggs! Luckily, the magical Seymour S. Sassafrass, the man who provides the bunnies with paint for their beloved Easter eggs, offers Peter the use of his holiday focused time machine so that he may go back to Easter morning and have a fair shot at handing out his eggs. But the time machine becomes damaged, and Peter soon finds himself having to improvise to get people to take his eggs at all. After all, who wants Easter eggs on Valentine's Day, Thanksgiving, Halloween, or Christmas?Told and sung by national treasure Danny Kaye as the delightful Seymour S. Sassafrass, "Here Comes Peter Cottontail" is a holiday treat full of wonderful songs and fantastic sights from those masters of the stop-motion holiday television special, Rankin and Bass! Originally aired in 1971, I remember waiting every year to see this special on television during the 1980's, and now we can all watch it whenever we like thanks to this great DVD from Sony Wonder. The show looks and sounds great, and it even comes with a few extras. You get sing-alongs, 3 cute bonus stories (Peter Rabbit, Polly's Pet, and The Little Red Hen, told using illustrations with very minor animation), a music video from the horrendous looking 2005 direct-to-video CGI sequel (Here Comes Peter Cottontail: The Movie), a behind-the-scenes trailer for that sequel that plays before the feature, and an alternate Spanish language track. Awful sequels aside though, with the wonderful story, songs, and visuals and the voice talents of Danny Kaye, Casey Kasem, and the legendary Vincent Price as nasty ol' Irontail, you'll definitely want to pick this DVD up if you remember loving it as a kid and especially if you have a child of your own to introduce it to! For a holiday that can be more fun than you think and that doesn't have nearly enough holiday specials devoted to it, you'll want this one on your shelf next to "It's the Easter Beagle, Charlie Brown" for sure!

reviewText: Anyone who grew up in the 60's or has children from that time period has to have fond memories of all the Rankin & Bass holiday TV specials. 'Here Comes Peter Cottontail' and 'The Easter Bunny Is Coming To Town' were two specials made by the animated puppet team devoted to the holiday."Cottontail" is the better of the two programs for a couple of reasons.1)"The Easter Bunny" special closely resembles another Rankin & Bass classic 'Santa Claus Is Coming To Town' and is not included on this DVD release, but is available on DVD.2)"Easter Bunny" seems to go on and on....'Here Comes Peter Cottontail' is a fast paced adventure that will keep children and the young at heart interested for it's entire running time. Danny Kaye and Vincent Price lend their voice talents to this cute holiday tale. I have the older edition from 2002 and the DVD transfer looks clean. There are a couple of extras on the disc, the best being one of the Rankin & Bass family fairy tales classics. I remembered the series once I saw the intro, you probably will too! The one tale included here is 'Puss In Boots'. There are a few sing along music videos as well of the tunes from the TV special. I wish they would release the entire Family Fairy Tale Classic series on DVD.Happy Easter everyone!
summary: RANKIN & BASS COTTON TALE EASTER SPECIAL IS THE BETTER OF THE TWO DEVOTED TO THIS HOLIDAY!

reviewText: This RANKIN/BASS classic is in my TOP 5 RANKIN/BASS specials.  With talents like DANNY KAYE, VINCENT PRICE, CASEY KASEM, JOAN GARDNER, PAUL FREES, etc., RANKIN/BASS couldn't go wrong.  It also features one of the very BEST Soundtracks by Jules Bass and Maury Laws!  Previous video releases have been in LP MODE and not up to par...I think you will find the DVD to exceed expectations.  It also has an episode of FESTIVAL OF FAMILY CLASSICS as a BONUS!  I am currently working on the DVD releases of MAD MONSTER PARTY, THE DAYDREAMER and THE WACKY WORLD OF MOTHER GOOSE w/ ANCHOR BAY to be released later this year.  They will feature the 35mm SONY prints and more extras than have been on other RANKIN/BASS DVDs!  EASTER will be GREAT this year with this DVD.  Hopefully, WARNER BROS. will issue THE EASTER BUNNY IS COMIN' TO TOWN (W/ FRED ASTAIRE) and THE FIRST EASTER RABBIT (W/ BURL IVES) on one DVD.  Rick Goldschmidt RANKIN/BASS
summary: It's here and the re-mastered print looks AMAZING!

reviewText: To me this delightful Easter special is everything that Easter should be for young children and adults alike. Coming from a far more innocent age of television "Here Comes Peter Cottontail", is one of the greatest creations from the Rankin and Bass team of animators who brought us of course the immortal television classics "Rudolph the Red Nosed Reindeer", and "Frosty the Snowman". Taking Easter as their theme here they have created a memorable lead character in the delightful Peter Cottontail and this special was a regular feature of our Easter viewing when I was growing up for many years. I still treasure this special now as an adult and in the beautifully restored DVD version of it now available I still marvel at the truly superb animation created here by this legendary team without the assistance of any computers. Definately an Easter classic, this funny and warm hearted story has most surely stood the test of time. In between my more religious themed viewing over this holiday I always include "Here Comes Peter Cottontail", and the other Rankin and Bass Easter themed special "The Easter Bunny is Comin' To Town", in my regular viewing and it's always a joy to revisit these "old friends", each Easter.
summary: Totally Delightful Easter Special From The Classic Team Of Rankin And Bass

reviewText: This is the story of young Peter Cottontail, who is in a race to become the new chief Easter Bunny. The story is told and sung by Danny Kaye, as Seymour S. Sassafras & Company. This film also features a grand villain, the evil January Q. Irontail, voiced masterfully by the great Vincent Price. THis story is written by the immortal Romeo Muller, who also created such great films as "Rudolph the Red Nosed Reindeer", "Frosty the Snowman", "The Little Drummer Boy", "Santa Claus is Comin' to Town", and many others. "Here comes Peter Cottontail is a holiday favorite and sure to please any family audience. Very worth while viewing and I highly reccomend it!
summary: One of the BEST Family Oriented Films EVER MADE!

reviewText: The program reviewed NOT nostalgia..I didn't grow up with this, for some reason being born in 68, it just didn't seem to be one I caught.... but....a time machine? The contest was to see who could hand out the most eggs FOR EASTER - even if you had a time machine and even accidentally went to the other holidays it wouldn't change the fact Peter lost the contest!! How did "Old Iron Tails" tail get ran over by a child that made him hate children? A bunny's tail is so small -- none of this script makes any sense at all...Rudolph is a classic this story was just a mess from top to tail. The problem is the holiday itself, since it doesn't really have an interesting story behind it, or any secondary characters, 99% of this had to be dreamed up - and it failed. I still appreciate the detailed stop motion and of course the wonky 70's production values, but sadly this bunny is hollow.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Here Comes Peter Cottontail" is another great Animagic treat from Rankin/Bass.  The picture on the DVD is great, and does full justice to this classic.Vincent Price's Irontail is one of the best villains in any holiday special.  There is a special evil flair to the character, a dark bunny who rides on a giant bat and only wants to deliver mud-colored eggs.  I love Danny Kaye, who does a great job as the narrator Seymour S. Sassafras.The best scenes are Peter trying to deliver holiday-themed eggs during competing holidays.  4th of July eggs, Valentine's Day eggs, Christmas eggs and green St. Patrick's Day eggs spring from his basket.  Our plucky little hero tries his best, and overcomes his self-inflicted follies in true holiday style.Sadly, the accompanying feature "Puss in Boots" is very low-quality Rankin/Bass.  It is a cheaply animated feature and does not fit well with "Here Comes Peter Cottontail."  There is no Easter theme to the cartoon, and I cannot see myself watching it more than once.  A better fit would have been "The Easter Bunny is Coming to Town" or "The First Easter Rabbit."  This tacked-on extra keeps the DVD from getting 5 stars.Other than that, great DVD!  More please.
